greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest number k such that the symmetric representation of sigma(k) has at least one part of width n.
comment: The 26 entries starting with 6 are products of powers of consecutive primes starting with 2, except for a(12)=32760 and a(15)=98280 (which are missing 11), and a(26)=942480 (which is missing 13).
In other words, a(n) is the smallest number k such that the symmetric representation of sigma(k) has n layers. For more information see A279387. - _Omar E. Pol_, Dec 16 2016
Row 1 of A253258. - _Omar E. Pol_, Apr 15 2018
formula: a(n) = min(k such that A250068(k) = n), n>=1.
example: a(60) = 3 since the symmetric representation of sigma(60) = 168 consists of a single region of whose successive widths are 41 1's, 9 2's, 6 3's, 7 2's, 6 3's, 9 2's, and 41 1's.
mathematica: (* function a2[ ] is defined in A249223 *)
a250070[{j_, k_}, b_] := Module[{i, max, acc={{1, 1}}}, For[i=j, i<=k, i++, max={Max[a2[i]], i}; If[max[[1]]>b && !MemberQ[Transpose[acc][[1]], max[[1]]], AppendTo[acc,max]]]; acc]
(* returns (argument,result) data pairs since sequence is non-monotonic *)
results.author: _Hartmut F. W. Hoft_, Nov 11 2014
